title: NASA closing its original repository for Columbia artifacts to tours
content:
NASA is changing the way that its employees come in contact with, and remember, one of its worst tragedies.

In the wake of the 2003 loss of the space shuttle Columbia and its STS-107 crew, NASA created a program to use the orbiter's debris for research and education at Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Agency employees were invited to see what remained of the space shuttle as a powerful reminder as to why they had to be diligent in their work. Access to the Columbia Research and Preservation Office, though, was limited as a result of its location and related logistics.

To address that and open up the experience to more of the workforce at Kennedy, the agency has quietly begun work to establish a new facility.

summary:
Key Takeaway: NASA is closing its original repository for Columbia artifacts and establishing a new facility to provide more employees access to these powerful reminders of the 2003 space shuttle tragedy.

Why it Matters: The Columbia disaster was a devastating event in NASA's history, and maintaining access to the artifacts serves as an important reminder for the agency's workforce to remain diligent in their work. Expanding employee access to these artifacts can help reinforce the lessons learned from the tragedy.

Brief Context: After the 2003 loss of the space shuttle Columbia and its crew, NASA created a program to use the orbiter's debris for research and education. However, access to the Columbia Research and Preservation Office was limited. To address this, NASA is now working to establish a new facility that will allow more of the workforce at Kennedy Space Center to engage with these important historical artifacts.

faq.question: Why is NASA closing the Columbia Research and Preservation Office?
faq.answer: nswer: NASA is closing the original repository for Columbia artifacts in order to establish a new facility that will allow more of the Kennedy Space Center workforce to access and view the remains of the space shuttle. The current location and logistics of the existing office have limited employee access, so the agency is working to create a new facility that will open up this experience to more people.

faq.question: What happened to the space shuttle Columbia?
faq.answer: nswer: The space shuttle Columbia was lost in 2003 during its STS-107 mission, resulting in the tragic death of the entire crew. The creation of the Columbia Research and Preservation Office was a way for NASA to preserve the debris and artifacts from the disaster as a powerful reminder to employees about the importance of diligence in their work.

faq.question: How will the new facility improve access to the Columbia artifacts?
faq.answer: nswer: The new facility that NASA is establishing will be designed to allow more of the Kennedy Space Center workforce to come and view the remains of the Columbia shuttle. The current office has been limited in access due to its location and related logistics, so the new setup will aim to open up this experience to a greater number of NASA employees as an ongoing reminder of the tragedy.

faq.question: What is the purpose of allowing NASA employees to view the Columbia artifacts?
faq.answer: nswer: Allowing NASA employees, especially those who work at Kennedy Space Center, to view the debris and artifacts from the Columbia disaster is meant to serve as a powerful reminder of the importance of their work. Seeing the physical remains of the shuttle is intended to reinforce the need for diligence and attention to detail in order to prevent such tragedies from occurring again.

faq.question: How will the transition to the new facility impact the preservation and research efforts around the Columbia artifacts?
faq.answer: nswer: While the article does not provide specific details, the fact that NASA is actively working to establish a new facility suggests that the agency is committed to continuing the preservation and research efforts around the Columbia artifacts. The goal appears to be improving access and exposure to these important historical and educational materials for the NASA workforce.
